newsitem.title: USA: CBOT corn ends lower amid rapid planting progress.
newsitem.headline: CBOT corn ends lower amid rapid planting progress.

text.p: CBOT corn futures closed lower, weakened by projections of rapid planting progress across the U.S. Midwest, dealers said.
"Planting progress is good and the crop is going in well," said Don Roose, president of U.S. Commodities.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture confirmed after the close, widespread talk of good progress, estimating 50 percent of the crop had been planted, as of Sunday, up from 18 percent last week and ahead of 40 percent at the same time last year.
Pit sources said Prudential Securities sold 15.0 million bushels of September corn on the day.
Featured buyers included Goldenberg Hehmeyer (7.0 million bushels December), traders said.
Dealers said weakness in wheat prices weighed on the market but strength in soybeans underpinned them.
"Corn doesn't have a life of its own," Roose said. "It's following wheat to a certain degree and it's caught in the support from soybeans."
July corn closed 1-1/2 cents lower at $2.91-3/4 with other months down 1-3/4 to four cents.
Corn futures volume was estimated at 67,000 contracts, above Friday's actual total of 61,001 contracts.
